﻿       Cinema Resources, NYU Cinema Studies Department                                                                                                                                                                                               The Department of Cinema Studies   SUMMER 2015 COURSE SCHEDULE   No appointment is required for undergraduate or graduate students to register for summer classes through Albert. For more registration info, click here .                              COURSES                            Almodovar   Espionage Film: Understanding 007   Close Analysis of Film            Kubrick   NYC on Film: Summer in the City   Music Videos                      FIRST SESSION                                   May 26 - June 13 (Session IA)   ALMODOVAR   Open to both graduate and undergraduate students     CINE-UT 220 (undergraduate) c#4944   NCRD-UT 4501 (undergraduate non-credit) c#6758   CINE-GT 2220 (graduate) c#4945   NCRD-GT 4501 (graduate non-credit) c#6759     Chris Straayer   MTWR, 12:30-4:30pm (T-F, M-R, M-W)   Pedro Almodóvar is the most notorious Spanish filmmaker since Luis Buñuel and, like Buñuel, rapidly gained international acclaim. This course will attend to Almodóvars appealing body of work ( What Have I Done to Deserve This, Matador, Law of Desire, Tie Me Up Tie Me Down, All About My Mother, Talk to Her, Bad Education, Volver, Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown, The Skin I Live In, among others) in relation to: national political history; international film exhibition; intertextual popular culture; comedy-thriller-melodrama genre mixing; convoluted narrative structures; theatrical uses of color, music, acting, and scale; interrelated themes of family, desire, and identity; and an aesthetics of excess. Finally we will consider the outstanding Almodóvar within a context of "influence."   NOTE: This course will meet Tuesday through Friday (first week), Monday through Thursday (second week) and Monday through Wednesday (third week).          May 26 - June 13 (Session IA)   ESPIONAGE FILM: UNDERSTANDING 007   Undergraduate Only   CINE-UT 247 c#4948   Jaap Verhuel   MTWR, 6:00-10:00pm  The release of Skyfall in 2012 coincided with the fiftieth anniversary of the James Bond franchise. Ever since the release of Dr. No in 1962, this illustrious icon of western popular culture has captivated  audiences across the globe, transgressing boundaries of ideology, nation, empire, gender, race,  ethnicity, age, and generation in spite of its blatantly white, heterosexual, and Eurocentric worldview.  Why is the misogynist dinosaur from the Cold War still so popular with female audiences today?  How do we explain the success of the offensively orientalist You Only Live Twice in Japan? Why do  queer audiences often favor Roger Moores raised eyebrow over Daniel Craigs blue speedo?  Chronicling the evolution of 007 over half a century of political, social, and cultural permutations, this  summer course will examine the historical and theoretical dimensions and discrepancies of the  James Bond phenomenon to understand its seemingly perpetual allure. films by Chabrol, Truffaut, Godard, Almodóvar, Argento, Spielberg, Lynch, Demme and de Palma.                                                        June 15 - July 2 (Session IB)   A CLOSE ANALYSIS OF FILM   Open to both graduate and undergraduate students     CINE-UT 290 (undergraduate) c#4949   NCRD-UT 4503 (undergraduate non-credit) c#6760   CINE-GT 2005 (graduate) c#6744   NCRD-GT 4503 (graduate non-credit) c#6761     Antonia Lant   MTWR, 10:00am-2:00pm   This class examines a small number of films in great detail with the intention of enhancing student comprehension of the multiple levels at which films are made and received.  Among the films we will  analyze are Touch of Evil (1958), Do the Right Thing (1989), In the Mood For Love (2000), Pans  Labyrinth (2006), Run, Lola, Run (1998), and Gilda (1946). The course encourages the intensive, and  comparative study of film, and concentrates on the formal analysis of the sound and image track, the  segmentation of the scenario/narrative, techniques of stylistic analysis, and a consideration of a films  surrounding documents, such as studio papers, posters, and critical reviews.   Students will acquire  vocabulary and tools through which to describe the textual patterns and forces by which a film  produces its meanings and effects.  As a key part of the course, each student will closely analyze an individual film they have chosen, for a final presentation.                                    June 15 - July 2 (Session IB)   KUBRICK   Open to both graduate and undergraduate students     CINE-UT 206 (undergraduate) c#4946   NCRD-UT 4502 (undergraduate non-credit) c#6764   CINE-GT 2202 (graduate) c#4947   NCRD-GT 4502 (graduate non-credit) c#6765     Bill Simon   MTWR, 3:00 - 7:00pm   The films of Stanley Kubrick constitute one of the most innovative bodies of work in the commercial  cinema. This course investigates Kubricks films in detail with emphasis on their narrative  conceptions and structures. The course will explore the uses of irony and voiceover, the  representation of the relationship between humans and technology, the centrality of the topic of war,  and the relationship of his films to issues of genre.      SECOND SESSION              July 6 - August 15   NYC ON FILM: SUMMER IN THE CITY   Undergraduate Only   CINE-UT 393 c#4950   Michael Bowen   MW, 12:30-4:30pm   This course examines New York Citys role as Americas second movie capital from the time of the  invention of motion pictures right up through the mid-1980s. Topics covered include: New Yorks  centrality to the creation of the American film industry in the early silent period; the Citys role as an  icon of modernity in Hollywood movies of the 1930s and 40s; and Manhattans emergence in the  Postwar period as a center for alternate filmmaking practices, especially independent and exploitation  features, underground experimental films, and early televisual forms such as direct cinema and  live anthology dramas. In sum, the course analyzes a set of generic and formal practices intimately  associated with Greater New York as well as offering an introduction to the Citys rich cultural history.  Screenings include Dog Day Afternoon (1975), Escape from New York (1981), King Kong (1933),  Breakfast at Tiffanys (1961), Midnight Cowboy (1969) and Twelve Angry Men (1954).                                                      July 6 - August 15   MUSIC VIDEOS   Undergraduate Only   CINE-UT 310 c#4952   Sylvie Vitaglione   TR, 12:30-4:30pm   Situated between art and advertisement, between television and experimental filmmaking, the music video sells much more than music. What used to be played on a loop on TV now gets millions of  views online, making the music video a must-have for any singer or band. These 3 to 5 minutes of  content can shape an artists career, launch a new dance or fashion trend, and even go viral like  Gangnam Style, the Harlem Shake and Happy. This course will examine the history and aesthetics of  music videos from MTV to YouTube and consider their impact on popular culture. As we view videos  from Michael Jackson, Madonna, Nirvana, Radiohead, Daft Punk, Bjork, Beyonce, Lady Gaga and  many others, we will question the politics of representation at work. We will study auteur directors  such as Spike Jonze, Michel Gondry and Chris Cunningham to question the relationship between  music videos and cinema.

﻿       Cinema Resources, NYU Cinema Studies Department                                                                                                                                                                                               The Department of Cinema Studies   SUMMER 2015 COURSE SCHEDULE   No appointment is required for undergraduate or graduate students to register for summer classes through Albert. For more registration info, click here .                              COURSES                            Almodovar   Espionage Film: Understanding 007   Close Analysis of Film            Kubrick   NYC on Film: Summer in the City   Music Videos                      FIRST SESSION                                   May 26 - June 13 (Session IA)   ALMODOVAR   Open to both graduate and undergraduate students     CINE-UT 220 (undergraduate) c#4944   NCRD-UT 4501 (undergraduate non-credit) c#6758   CINE-GT 2220 (graduate) c#4945   NCRD-GT 4501 (graduate non-credit) c#6759     Chris Straayer   MTWR, 12:30-4:30pm (T-F, M-R, M-W)   Pedro Almodóvar is the most notorious Spanish filmmaker since Luis Buñuel and, like Buñuel, rapidly gained international acclaim. This course will attend to Almodóvars appealing body of work ( What Have I Done to Deserve This, Matador, Law of Desire, Tie Me Up Tie Me Down, All About My Mother, Talk to Her, Bad Education, Volver, Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown, The Skin I Live In, among others) in relation to: national political history; international film exhibition; intertextual popular culture; comedy-thriller-melodrama genre mixing; convoluted narrative structures; theatrical uses of color, music, acting, and scale; interrelated themes of family, desire, and identity; and an aesthetics of excess. Finally we will consider the outstanding Almodóvar within a context of "influence."   NOTE: This course will meet Tuesday through Friday (first week), Monday through Thursday (second week) and Monday through Wednesday (third week).          May 26 - June 13 (Session IA)   ESPIONAGE FILM: UNDERSTANDING 007   Undergraduate Only   CINE-UT 247 c#4948   Jaap Verhuel   MTWR, 6:00-10:00pm  The release of Skyfall in 2012 coincided with the fiftieth anniversary of the James Bond franchise. Ever since the release of Dr. No in 1962, this illustrious icon of western popular culture has captivated  audiences across the globe, transgressing boundaries of ideology, nation, empire, gender, race,  ethnicity, age, and generation in spite of its blatantly white, heterosexual, and Eurocentric worldview.  Why is the misogynist dinosaur from the Cold War still so popular with female audiences today?  How do we explain the success of the offensively orientalist You Only Live Twice in Japan? Why do  queer audiences often favor Roger Moores raised eyebrow over Daniel Craigs blue speedo?  Chronicling the evolution of 007 over half a century of political, social, and cultural permutations, this  summer course will examine the historical and theoretical dimensions and discrepancies of the  James Bond phenomenon to understand its seemingly perpetual allure. films by Chabrol, Truffaut, Godard, Almodóvar, Argento, Spielberg, Lynch, Demme and de Palma.                                                        June 15 - July 2 (Session IB)   A CLOSE ANALYSIS OF FILM   Open to both graduate and undergraduate students     CINE-UT 290 (undergraduate) c#4949   NCRD-UT 4503 (undergraduate non-credit) c#6760   CINE-GT 2005 (graduate) c#6744   NCRD-GT 4503 (graduate non-credit) c#6761     Antonia Lant   MTWR, 10:00am-2:00pm   This class examines a small number of films in great detail with the intention of enhancing student comprehension of the multiple levels at which films are made and received.  Among the films we will  analyze are Touch of Evil (1958), Do the Right Thing (1989), In the Mood For Love (2000), Pans  Labyrinth (2006), Run, Lola, Run (1998), and Gilda (1946). The course encourages the intensive, and  comparative study of film, and concentrates on the formal analysis of the sound and image track, the  segmentation of the scenario/narrative, techniques of stylistic analysis, and a consideration of a films  surrounding documents, such as studio papers, posters, and critical reviews.   Students will acquire  vocabulary and tools through which to describe the textual patterns and forces by which a film  produces its meanings and effects.  As a key part of the course, each student will closely analyze an individual film they have chosen, for a final presentation.                                    June 15 - July 2 (Session IB)   KUBRICK   Open to both graduate and undergraduate students     CINE-UT 206 (undergraduate) c#4946   NCRD-UT 4502 (undergraduate non-credit) c#6764   CINE-GT 2202 (graduate) c#4947   NCRD-GT 4502 (graduate non-credit) c#6765     Bill Simon   MTWR, 3:00 - 7:00pm   The films of Stanley Kubrick constitute one of the most innovative bodies of work in the commercial  cinema. This course investigates Kubricks films in detail with emphasis on their narrative  conceptions and structures. The course will explore the uses of irony and voiceover, the  representation of the relationship between humans and technology, the centrality of the topic of war,  and the relationship of his films to issues of genre.      SECOND SESSION              July 6 - August 15   NYC ON FILM: SUMMER IN THE CITY   Undergraduate Only   CINE-UT 393 c#4950   Michael Bowen   MW, 12:30-4:30pm   This course examines New York Citys role as Americas second movie capital from the time of the  invention of motion pictures right up through the mid-1980s. Topics covered include: New Yorks  centrality to the creation of the American film industry in the early silent period; the Citys role as an  icon of modernity in Hollywood movies of the 1930s and 40s; and Manhattans emergence in the  Postwar period as a center for alternate filmmaking practices, especially independent and exploitation  features, underground experimental films, and early televisual forms such as direct cinema and  live anthology dramas. In sum, the course analyzes a set of generic and formal practices intimately  associated with Greater New York as well as offering an introduction to the Citys rich cultural history.  Screenings include Dog Day Afternoon (1975), Escape from New York (1981), King Kong (1933),  Breakfast at Tiffanys (1961), Midnight Cowboy (1969) and Twelve Angry Men (1954).                                                      July 6 - August 15   MUSIC VIDEOS   Undergraduate Only   CINE-UT 310 c#4952   Sylvie Vitaglione   TR, 12:30-4:30pm   Situated between art and advertisement, between television and experimental filmmaking, the music video sells much more than music. What used to be played on a loop on TV now gets millions of  views online, making the music video a must-have for any singer or band. These 3 to 5 minutes of  content can shape an artists career, launch a new dance or fashion trend, and even go viral like  Gangnam Style, the Harlem Shake and Happy. This course will examine the history and aesthetics of  music videos from MTV to YouTube and consider their impact on popular culture. As we view videos  from Michael Jackson, Madonna, Nirvana, Radiohead, Daft Punk, Bjork, Beyonce, Lady Gaga and  many others, we will question the politics of representation at work. We will study auteur directors  such as Spike Jonze, Michel Gondry and Chris Cunningham to question the relationship between  music videos and cinema.

FacultySpotlightFredCarl: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Graduate Musical Theatre Writing About the Program Course Offerings News & Events Summer Alumni Admin & Faculty Newsletter Facebook Twitter YouTube  home > Graduate Musical Theatre Writing        Faculty Spotlight: An Interview with Fred Carl About His New Musical A CLOCKWORK ORANGE   Fred Carl (Full Time Faculty and Cycle 4) and his collaborator Ed DuRante (Cycle 7) are creating a musical adaptation of A Clockwork Orange that will be produced in England at the Theatre Royal Stratford East in September of 2011. Kerry Mitchell, the artistic director of Stratford East, told The Stage News, “It’s something between a musical and a play. It’s not really a traditional musical. There is dialogue that goes into song, there is spoken word. It’s very sexy and sophisticated, and very smart.”    To find out more about the show, visit the WEBSITE .      AN INTERVIEW WITH FRED CARL BY GMTWP NEWSLETTER EDITOR JENNY STAFFORD (Cycle 20)    Carl, who is writing the music for the piece, was kind enough to answer some questions about the process of writing A Clockwork Orange .    Jenny Stafford: I know you’ve been involved with Stratford East for a long time. How did you first start working with them, and how did A Clockwork Orange come about?    Fred Carl: Robert Lee and I started working with Theatre Royal Stratford East in 1999. The then artistic director, Philip Hedley, and a younger theater associate who is now a successful writer, director and film actor, Clint Dyer, met Sarah (Schlesinger) at a conference in London during the summer of 1998. Sarah invited them to come by the Program if they ever found themselves in NY; about 5 weeks later, they showed up and stayed for 5 weeks, attending classes and generally participating in everything going on at the time. The theatre was closed for a major refurbishment and Philip decided to start a musical theatre writing initiative. He invited Robert and I to help design and co-lead a summer writing workshop for people who wrote in more contemporary, urban styles than what was usually seen/heard in British musical theatre. Over the 12 years of the Musical Theatre Workshop, Robert and I have worked with about 200 writers and composers, some of whom have gone on to transfer shows from Stratford East to the West End; we were also invited to be Artistic Associates of the theatre. A Clockwork Orange came about because Kerry Michael, the current Artistic Director, wanted to see a musical theatre adaptation of the piece and he offered me and my collaborator, Ed DuRante a commission to adapt the Anthony Burgess novel. We read the book and were both very excited by it. I, frankly, was never a huge fan of the Stanley Kubrick movie—I was always a bit put off by the way the film ends, which follows the early American editions of the book where Anthony Burgess’s last chapter was omitted. In that last chapter, since restored to the most recent American editions, Alex realizes that he no longer wants to be a criminal…he starts to want to make more creative use of his time. He realizes this after he runs into a former gang member who is now married and who is in the process of creating a family. Alex realizes that he no longer wants what he always wanted—to wreak havoc. This ending gave us the possibility for change. So we accepted the commission.    JS: What kind of challenges have you faced adapting such a well-known work—particularly one that’s also been made into a film? How have you and Ed put your own “spin” on it?    FC: We decided pretty much from the start that we wanted to set the piece in a world inhabited mostly by people of color, so Alex and most of the cast are black. This had implications for the language—Burgess devised a language for the teenaged gang members that he called Nadsat, which is a combination of proper English, Russian and Cockney slang. So the language that Ed has devised is a combination of contemporary British, Afro-British and African American language. We also decided to, at least at the start of our process, to retain Burgess’s 3-part structure—the novel is divided into 3 parts, each of which has 7 chapters, so that by the end, Alex has metaphorically reached the “age of majority”, has in effect reached adulthood. The novel doesn’t really have any significant female characters; Alex’s mother and a few of his victims are female, but we decided to add a significant female character who provides another voice urging him to start to make different choices with his life. One trick was to avoid turning the story into A Clockwork Orange , a love story. In the novel and the film, Alex has a special relationship with classical music, mostly, it seems, big orchestral music from the late 18th/early 19th centuries. When he loses his ability to choose between right and wrong, he also loses this relationship with the music he loves….in fact, any deep feeling causes him to be violently ill. Obviously, we had to rethink his relationship with music for a musical theatre piece. The look of the piece will also be very different from the movie.    JS: How would you describe the musical style of the show? What’s influenced your choices?    FC: The musical styles for the most part live in a groove-based world: we dip into hip-hop, spoken word, R&B, and Afro-Cuban stylistic places, as well as a harmonic language informed by post-1960s jazz styles and some contemporary “classical” styles. Part of that decision came from where I like to live as a composer these days, as well as the kinds of music that I, as a listener, respond to and that I have felt I have been missing in a lot of musical theatre that I see. Sometimes the music is something that might be familiar to Alex and his gang. Looking at the score in rehearsals I’ve noticed that it’s full of major/minor dissonances…..I guess I like that.    JS: Have you found any differences preparing a show for a London premier as opposed to an American premier? Has that had any influence on how you’ve approached the piece?    FC: One interesting thing that I’ve not experienced before is that the entire cast spent three days doing a very close reading of the piece, for the purpose of discovering each dramatic beat of the piece—everyone participated in the discussion, not just the actors playing the characters involved in that beat. Each beat was given a title that was agreed on by everyone. By the end of this “unit-ing” process, the entire room was in agreement on what piece they were about to play. The director has constantly referred to these discoveries throughout the rehearsal process. Another nice thing is the afternoon tea break—essentially a regular Equity break, but everybody goes and gets tea or coffee and cookies….that’s fun.    JS: What’s been the most rewarding part of the process so far?    FC: There is sooo much that is rewarding—watching the piece come to life on these actors is thrilling. For the past few days I’ve been watching and listening and finding it hard to believe that we wrote this thing that is taking shape before our eyes. Hopefully, it will be well-received, but regardless of what happens in that area, watching other people find the things that you thought you were saying and making them their own is a blast.    JS: How does your work as a composer influence your work as a professor, and visa versa?    FC: Good question—with this piece I’ve had the opportunity to put into practice a lot of what I’m always telling students—write the kind of music that turns you on and try to figure out how to make it serve a dramatic function. I’ve felt that groove-based music is so under-utilized in musical theatre, but so well-known and loved in the world; this is an experiment to see how well I could make it work….once we get audiences in, I guess we’ll see what they think. And now if any student complains about their workload, I can tell one of the many stories that I’ll come back with about staying up late and writing and having actors look at you each day and say, “Is my new song ready yet?” “Uh, in two days….ok?”           Undergraduate Admissions Graduate Admissions Academic Services Student Life Financial Aid and Scholarships Career Development Counseling Services International Students Incoming Students Graduation Forms What is Special Programs?
